pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw:
Can you explain the reason for making this into a shared pointer? Will its ownership be shared with others?

Since `gui::DataLogger` inherits from `QDialog` and we give it a parent, we should be safe to assume Qt will take care of its lifetime. I believe that's why we were originally keeping just a raw pointer to it.
content.html:
Can you explain the reason for making this into a shared pointer? Will its ownership be shared with others?

Since gui::DataLogger inherits from QDialog and we give it a parent, we should be safe to assume Qt will take care of its lifetime. I believe that's why we were originally keeping just a raw pointer to it.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: You are right, there is no need to use a shared pointer in that case. I reverted it back and made sure that its callbacks are destroyed in `DataLogger~DataLogger()`.
content.html: You are right, there is no need to use a shared pointer in that case. I reverted it back and made sure that its callbacks are destroyed in DataLogger~DataLogger().

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: The main issue was that the list of callbacks in `Publication` was not properly cleared after a gzclient exited. So, I would recommend launching a gzserver and monitor the list of `Publication::callbacks` when one or several gzclients are launched and after they exit.
content.html: The main issue was that the list of callbacks in Publication was not properly cleared after a gzclient exited. So, I would recommend launching a gzserver and monitor the list of Publication::callbacks when one or several gzclients are launched and after they exit.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: Could you explain the reason for moving this to the end? I think it could actually be moved up, so we clean all transport before cleaning up the rest. The reason is that we want to clean up callbacks which might try to access other members, such as `mouseMoveVis` before the members become null.
content.html: Could you explain the reason for moving this to the end? I think it could actually be moved up, so we clean all transport before cleaning up the rest. The reason is that we want to clean up callbacks which might try to access other members, such as mouseMoveVis before the members become null.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: You are right, I should not have moved it.
content.html: You are right, I should not have moved it.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: It is safer to reset the subscribers and publishers before calling `node->Fini()` so I made the changes.
content.html: It is safer to reset the subscribers and publishers before calling node->Fini() so I made the changes.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: Can we move this node reset to be right after node fini? Just want to make sure all the callbacks are properly terminated before deleting the mutexes. It should be enough to reset the subscriber to terminate a callback but I'm not sure this has been well tested yet.
content.html: Can we move this node reset to be right after node fini? Just want to make sure all the callbacks are properly terminated before deleting the mutexes. It should be enough to reset the subscriber to terminate a callback but I'm not sure this has been well tested yet.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw:
The [Subscriber](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/08b0b80c8a74498e5876eac82bf68e1c52ad0e9b/gazebo/transport/Subscriber.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Subscriber.cc-40)'s destructor calls `Unsubscribe`, which uses the node to unsubscribe it in the `TopicManager` and to remove the callback within the node.

Node [Fini](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/08b0b80c8a74498e5876eac82bf68e1c52ad0e9b/gazebo/transport/Node.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Node.cc-50) does clear all callbacks, but it doesn't unsubscribe each subscriber from the topic manager for example.
content.html:
The Subscriber's destructor calls Unsubscribe, which uses the node to unsubscribe it in the TopicManager and to remove the callback within the node.

Node Fini does clear all callbacks, but it doesn't unsubscribe each subscriber from the topic manager for example.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: I don't think there is a problem with this. It's functionally equivalent to the Node destroying publishers and subscribers after the Fini call in its destructor.
content.html: I don't think there is a problem with this. It's functionally equivalent to the Node destroying publishers and subscribers after the Fini call in its destructor.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.html:
I did a little digging. Try for example adding the following warning message:

diff -r 183ffd507ae0 gazebo/transport/TopicManager.cc
--- a/gazebo/transport/TopicManager.cc  Fri Jul 01 14:35:59 2016 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/transport/TopicManager.cc  Tue Jul 12 18:18:14 2016 -0700
@@ -260,8 +260,14 @@
   if (publication)
     publication->RemoveSubscription(_node);

-  ConnectionManager::Instance()->Unsubscribe(_topic,
-      _node->GetMsgType(_topic));
+  auto msgType = _node->GetMsgType(_topic);
+  if (msgType.empty())
+  {
+    gzwarn << "Trying to unsubscribe topic [" << _topic <<
+        "] but message type is unknown" << std::endl;
+  }
+
+  ConnectionManager::Instance()->Unsubscribe(_topic, msgType);

   this->subscribedNodes[_topic].remove(_node);
 }

The way it currently is, we see a warning message every time we click on the screen, for example.

However, if we move node->Fini to be below the pub and sub resets, we don't get the warning when clicking.

I'm not sure if not having the message type at that point is critical or not. But this example illustrates how the Pub and Sub destructors are counting on the node's internal state, so we shouldn't clean that internal state before destroying pub and sub.

pullrequest.title: Make sure gzserver destroys all callbacks when gzclient exits

content.raw: looking through the code, I see that `node.Fini() / reset()` are all called after pub and sub reset so I believe the comment's been addressed.
content.html: looking through the code, I see that node.Fini() / reset() are all called after pub and sub reset so I believe the comment's been addressed.
